bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, April 21, 1939

div1.p: Hench reveals his thoughts on Kissinger. He expresses his continued interest in the yellow fever story.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, April 21, 1939
div1.opener:
Yellow Fever
April 21, 1939
Mr. John J. Moran
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.
Avenida Menocal Nos. 455-57
Habana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I was indeed interested to hear from you again. Indeed, I have not dropped
the Reed-Finlay matter. Not realizing that there was any particular conflict in
the matter, my original intention was to obtain a straight-forward story from
Kissinger and one from you and publish these with brief comments in a journal
devoted to medical history, where they would be on record, in your own words, for
the medical profession of all time. Then when I found that Kissinger's comments
did not agree with some of yours, and when I found that Reed's reports did not
agree with one or two of the other reports in the Congressional Record, I began
to see that the story wasn't a simple one to unravel. I talked over with Kissinger
when he visited us a number of the points in dispute, and of course part of the
errors are simply due to the lapse of time and forgetfulness. Others may be mistakes
that have come into his story simply because he has lived the story for so many
years. You see, frankly Mr. Kissinger was not as fortunate as you. As far as
he is concerned, his life more or less ended with the Havana experience, and
he has been living that experience over ever since, on the insistence of friends
who have asked him to tell the story over and over again. You, on the other hand,
have continued an active, energetic life, most of the time too busy to spend much
time telling the story of the Havana experience. You can see, therefore, how he
could, without any wrong intent, dramatize his experience after so many tellings.

I have been collecting old books on the yellow fever story and I am preparing
to do considerable research on the matter. It is my sincere hope that I can take
my vacation next March partly in Florida and partly in Havana, and I am greatly
hoping that you will be there at that time and that I can spend three or four more
days in Havana, by which time I will have some definite inquiries to make of you
that you can help me straighten out the contradictions. If at all possible, I am
hopeful that you will be able to guide me to the original camp and show me some
of the historical features. With your approval, I should like to bring my camera
and make a few photographs to illustrate the story later. Rest assured that nothing
is to be done that you and Mr. Kissinger, and others interested, will not know fully
about before its publication. You can see it is going to be a matter of many months,
perhaps two or three years, before things are ironed out, and I will most assuredly
appreciate your help.

I am sorry indeed to hear that you were so very ill, but delighted to know
that you are now improved. I am particularly interested in rheumatic diseases and
am not much of a stomach specialist. At any rate, any advice that I could give you
Mr. John J. Moran
- 2 -
April 21, 1939
by mail wouldn't be worth much, but if there is any way we can cooperate with your
attending physician, either now or in the future, I am yours to command.

Incidentally, apropos of the clipping which you sent me, Mr. Kissinger
was really misquoted, and this article is not fair to him. He was most careful
to mention your name repeatedly during the talk and spoke in the highest terms
of you. At no time did he minimize in the slightest degree your contribution,
and I am sure your friends would have been completely satisfied and proud to have
heard the things he said about you.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
